transcripts.text: Not surprisingly, we're back with the race for 2020.  And our NBC News national polling average shows Joe Biden is up nearly eight points nationally over the president.  The averages in battleground states are showing a tighter race as Joe Biden has leads in Florida, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan.  While the president appears to have a slight edge in Ohio, of course, many of these still within the margin of error.  But the president is giving a different take on where the race stands.

But I think we're doing very well.  The numbers are coming in unbelievably well.  I don't believe the media is talking about them.  I'm not sure the media knows exactly what's happening yet.  But in Florida, we're doing very well.  North Carolina doing very well.  Iowa doing very well.  We're going to have a great red wave.  It's going to be a red wave like you've never seen before.

Well, joining me now is Michael Moore, filmmaker and host of the podcast Rumble with Michael Moore.  Welcome to you, Michael.  What do you think of what the president said there?  Do you think the media doesn't really know things and that it's going to be a big red wave?
The last time I remember hearing about a red wave, the Egyptians were chasing Moses across the Red Sea.  And that didn't turn out too well for the Egyptians.  Okay.

Until the morning comes up with this stuff.  It's a Sunday.  It's a church day.  I appreciate the Old Testament relevance.  OK, let's go to the poll numbers, though.  We shared the ones that have Biden mostly in the lead.  But then you hear the president with those predictions nine days to go, whether it's in your state of Michigan or anywhere else in this country.  Michael, are you seeing any red flags that suggest the president can pull this out and repeat that success that was unexpected by most in 2016?

Yeah, I understand why four years ago most people thought that he was going to lose.  Listen, anything can happen, obviously.  And everybody between now and Election Day should operate as if anything can happen.  Nobody should be smug.  You know the football players who do the end zone dance on the two-yard line?  before they cross over the goal.  They think they've already scored the touchdown and they get whacked from behind.  That's what happened in 2016.  I think we have to make sure that nobody does that end zone dance too early.  Having said that, I think that... I think actually the opposite of what Trump thinks.  The media are playing it so careful now because of the mistakes that were made by nearly every pundit back in 2016, including the New York Times on the front page of Election Day, where they said that Trump had only a 15 percent chance of winning.  Everybody's so afraid now of not doing that this time that maybe they also can't see how things are going to go this year, how they more than likely are going to go.  You've got a president that has done everything he can to lose, to the point where I've been wondering some days, does he really want to win?  First of all, why would any other president would have seized the coronavirus, taken the reins, and tried to bend the hero?  Especially when this was killing, his largest demographic in 2016 was over 65.  Instead of coming to their aid and defense, he let them die.  And now we're now having this huge wave, the largest day ever with coronavirus was, I think, Friday.  You know, you've had Dr.  Redliner on MSNBC saying this could get to 2,500 deaths a day.  why Trump would be killing off his voters, historians and political scientists are going to have to figure this out in the future.  But to do that and to, you know, 70% of the eligible voters a week from Tuesday are either women, people of color, or young adults between 18 and 35.  I've just named the three groups that detest Donald Trump the most.  And that's the wave he's facing.  The people that he has offended, the people that he has made bigoted comments about, that's what's facing him now.  And the fact that he has tried to suppress the vote, has tried to make it so hard for people to vote.  Who would try to prevent people from voting other than the person who believes he's going to lose?  Because you don't want people voting.  You want to reduce the vote.  If you thought you were going to win, you'd make it so easy for people to cast their ballots, to make sure every ballot was counted, every ballot got there by the post office.  He's done the opposite.  He's just admitting then that he knows that the American people are sick and tired.  of these four years and cannot wait to see him go.

So, you know, Michael, you talk about those groups that you say he's offended and they're the ones who really dislike him the most and they're the ones who are going to be in Joe Biden's camp here.  Do you think when you hear Trump campaign officials or just administration officials, they come out and say, look, We understand that maybe he's not for everybody, personality-wise.  But he's accomplished so many great things.  Vote for him because of his record, not because you maybe don't like the way he says something or his phrases.  I mean, is there any validity to that?

His record of what?  The official unemployment numbers right now are 23 million Americans without a job.  It's probably much higher than that.  A record where people are just struggling to get by all the small businesses that have closed, many of them permanently.  The economy is wrecked.  The coronavirus response has cost the lives of tens, if not hundreds of thousands of people.  What has been his great accomplishment?  Moving our embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem?  I'll tell you, out there in Milwaukee and Flint, that really put food on the table tonight.  No, I'm telling you, he has so ruined every chance he might have had.  What he'll have is he'll have his base.  Those 63 million that voted for him in 2016, I'm confident they will be there for him a week from Tuesday.  But that 63 million, you had Nate Silver on here, right?

No.  63 million he had.  But Nate Silver and others are suggesting that we may have 165 million voting, 30 million more than last time.  Where is he picking up those new votes?  Do you realize that Hillary won by 3 million?  Biden could win.  Again, I'm not to please people at home.  Don't sit back in your chair and go, oh, I don't need to go vote.  We're OK here.

No, but he could have blown it.  He might blow it as bad to lose by 10 million votes this time.  It's important, though.  That's why you have to vote.  Oh, yeah.  Because just winning the popular vote, as we know, isn't enough.  To guarantee to win the Electoral College means it has to be crushed.  There has to be a tsunami, a tsunami of ballots.

To prevent the kind of fears of election repercussions and going through something like we did back in 2000.  Absolutely correct.  Michael Moore, listen, I love having you on, but unfortunately, I'm out of time.  My EP is saying you've got to go.
I'm so grateful.  Thank you for letting me talk to you.  And I appreciate it.

I enjoy it.  Okay, I'm sure our viewers do too.  Thanks, Michael.  And that's going to do it for me, as we indicated for this hour, everyone.  I'm Alex Witt.  Thanks so much for watching.  I'll see you Saturday at noon Eastern next weekend.
